articles.headline: Bill Would Raise Taxes on Public Equity Firms
articles.snippet: New legislation could increase taxes on publicly traded private equity firms and hedge funds, a move that could dampen interest in the Blackstone Group.
articles.abstract: New legislation could increase taxes on publicly traded private equity firms and hedge funds, a move that could dampen interest in the Blackstone Group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Talk about trying to rain on their parade.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: A Tower of Babel in Accounting?
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. is expected to propose a rule that would allow foreign companies using international accounting standards to stop reconciling their financial statements to U.S. rules.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. is expected to propose a rule that would allow foreign companies using international accounting standards to stop reconciling their financial statements to U.S. rules.

articles.headline: Palestinian Split Deepens; Government in Chaos
articles.snippet: With Hamas tightening its control of the Gaza Strip amid more bloodshed, the Palestinian territories seemed headed toward a turbulent political divide.
articles.abstract: With Hamas tightening its control of the Gaza Strip amid more bloodshed, the Palestinian territories seemed headed toward a turbulent political divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM, June 14 — The Palestinian territories seemed headed Thursday to a turbulent political divide. Masked Hamas gunmen took control of the Gaza Strip and the Fatah president dissolved the 3-month-old unity government, declaring a state of emergency and plans for elections.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Rising Rates Squeeze Consumers and Companies
articles.snippet: The fallout from rising yields on the 10-year Treasury note is likely to be felt most immediately by homeowners and people looking to buy a house.
articles.abstract: The fallout from rising yields on the 10-year Treasury note is likely to be felt most immediately by homeowners and people looking to buy a house.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unusually low interest rates of the last three years have been an enormous boon to almost every corner of the American economy.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Sri Lanka’s Scars Trace Lines of War Without End
articles.snippet: The city of Jaffna is the trophy that soldiers and rebels have fought over for nearly 25 years in Sri Lanka’s ethnic civil war.
articles.abstract: The city of Jaffna is the trophy that soldiers and rebels have fought over for nearly 25 years in Sri Lanka’s ethnic civil war.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAFFNA, Sri Lanka — The nights here are once again broken by artillery fire across the black lagoon. The road out of this peninsula has been closed since last August, making the area nearly inaccessible. Though food and fuel manage to arrive, shopkeepers are reluctant to keep stocks, not knowing when they may have to close up and run.

articles.headline: More Trouble in Subprime Mortgages
articles.snippet: Delinquencies and foreclosures among homeowners with weak credit moved higher in the first quarter.
articles.abstract: Delinquencies and foreclosures among homeowners with weak credit moved higher in the first quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Delinquencies and foreclosures among homeowners with weak credit moved higher in the first quarter, particularly in California, Florida and other formerly hot real estate markets, according to an industry report released on Thursday.

articles.headline: To Avoid Conflicts, Clintons Liquidate Holdings
articles.snippet: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton liquidated a trust valued at $5 million to $25 million, leaving the proceeds in cash.
articles.abstract: Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton liquidated a trust valued at $5 million to $25 million, leaving the proceeds in cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 14 — Concerned that their personal finances might become a political liability once again, Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton in April sold the millions of dollars of stocks held by their blind trust after learning that those investments included oil and pharmaceutical companies, military contractors and Wal-Mart, their aides said Thursday.

articles.headline: Boom Times for Banks in Venezuela
articles.snippet: President Hugo Chávez’s economic policies have been generating a boom for those most capitalist of institutions — Venezuela’s banks.
articles.abstract: President Hugo Chávez’s economic policies have been generating a boom for those most capitalist of institutions — Venezuela’s banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — In marathon speeches peppered with quotes from Marx and accolades to Che Guevara, President Hugo Chávez repeatedly vows to do away with capitalism in Venezuela. But it turns out that Mr. Chávez’s economic policies have been generating a boom for those most capitalist of institutions — Venezuela’s banks.

articles.headline: Assisting the Good Life
articles.snippet: A golf resort in Oregon benefits from a variety of hidden subsidies, the kind of indirect favors that influence the flow of money from public to private interests.
articles.abstract: A golf resort in Oregon benefits from a variety of hidden subsidies, the kind of indirect favors that influence the flow of money from public to private interests.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANDON, Ore. — Mike Keiser, who made a fortune selling greeting cards on recycled paper, turned this remote spot on the southern Oregon coast into a golfing mecca that attracts wealthy people in private jets from around the world.
